FileSystem.Contents:
#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Change directory
#help cd is used to change your current directory. It accepts one path argument, relative or absolute. You can also put . to stay in the same directory, or .. to go one directory above.
Syntax: cd <path>
Examples:
cd ~/users/admin # Navigating using absolute path
cd desktop # Navigating using relative path
cd ../../directory # Going two directories above and to another
cd ././././ # Stay in the same directory
cd

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc List files in a directory
#help ls is used to view contents of a directory. Provide 0 arguments to view the current directory, provide 1 path argument to view specified directory.
Syntax: ls [path]
Examples:
ls # List current directory
ls ~/users # List specified directory 
ls

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Create a file
#help file is used to create a file in the current directory. It requires 1 argument: file name.\nSyntax: file <path>\nExamples:\nfile test.txt # Create a file named "test.txt"\n
file ~/users/admin/test.txt # Create a file named "test.txt" in the specified directory
file

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Rename a file/directory
#help rename is used to rename a file or directory.\nSyntax: rename <path> <newName>\nExamples:\nrename ~/users/admin/test.txt a.txt # Renames a file named test.txt to "a.txt"
rename

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Recursively delete a file/directory
#help del is used to delete a file or a directory. USE WITH CAUTION! It cannot be undone, and will delete every file available inside a directory
Syntax: del <path>
Examples:
del test.txt # Delete a file named test.txt
del ~/users/temp # Recursively delete a folder named temp
del

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Create a directory
#help dir is used to create a directory in the current one. It requires 1 argument: directory name.
Syntax: dir <path>
Examples:
dir test # Create a directory named "test"
dir ~/users/admin/test # Create a directory named "test" in the specified directory
dir

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc A simple lightweight text editor.
#help txt is used to quickly edit files. It requires 1 argument: path to a file.
Syntax: txt <path>
Examples:
txt file.txt # Opens "file.txt" in the editor
txt ~/users/admin/file.txt # Opens "file.txt" in the editor
txt

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc See the tree view of a directory
#help tree is used to efficiently inspect the inner contents of a directory in a tree-like view. It accepts 0 or 1 path argument.
Syntax: tree [path]
Examples:
tree # Tree view of the current directory.
tree ~ # Tree view of the whole system.
tree ~/users # Tree view of the specified directory
tree

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Authorize as a user
#help auth is used to authorize as a user. It accepts 1, 2 or 3 arguments - username, optional access level, optional runmode. A new terminal instance is created, unless specified otherwise
Syntax: auth <username> [accesslevel] [this|new]
Examples:
auth admin # Authorize as user "admin" with access level 0
auth admin 5 # Authorize as user "admin" with access level 5
auth admin max # Authorize as user "admin" with the max available access level
auth admin 3 this # Authorize as user "admin" with access level 3 without creating a new terminal 
auth

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc View file permissions
#help permslist is used to quickly check what permissions a file or a directory has. It requires 0 or 1 path argument.
Syntax: permslist [path]
Examples:
permslist file.txt # Displays permissions of a file named "file.txt"
permslist ~/users/admin # Displays permissions of the specified directory.
permslist # Displays permissions of the current directory
permslist

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc File permission editor
#help perms is used as a powerful file/directory permission editor. You cannot edit permissions of a file, if you do not have the required MANAGE access. It requires 0 or 1 path argument.
Syntax: perms [path]
Examples:
perms file.txt # Edit permissions of a file named "file.txt"
perms ~/users/admin # Edit permissions of the specified directory
perms # Edit permissions of the current directory
perms

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc A command terminal
#help terminal is used to launch a terminal which can execute user commands or scripts. The new terminal will have the same user as the parent, but access level will be set to 0.\nSyntax: terminal\nExamples:\nterminal # Starts a terminal
terminal

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Kill the terminal process
#help kill is used to kill the terminal you are in.\nSyntax: kill\nExamples:\nkill # Kills the terminal.
kill

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Run an executable
#help run is used to run executable (.exe) files. It requires 1 or 2 pre-specified arguments: executable file path and an optional run mode. If more than 2 arguments will be provided, they will be used as the executable arguments.
Syntax: run <path> [mode]
Examples:
run a.exe # Run an executable named "a.exe"
run a.exe new # Runs an executable named "a.exe" in the new terminal.
run ~/system/installed/tree.exe this ~/users # Runs "tree.exe" in the current terminal and provides "~/users" as an argument. This is equivalent to "tree ~/users"  
run

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Help command
#help help is used to list all available commands and display info about them, or to provide help a specific command.
Syntax: help [command]
Examples:
help # Lists all installed commands
help cd # Provides help on cd command
help

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc Display user text
#help say is used to display the specified text in the terminal. It requires 2 arguments: color and text in double-quotes.
Syntax: say <color> "<text>"
Examples:
say #FFFFFF "test test" # Displays "test test" in color white
say #FF0000 "error error" # Displays "error error" in color red.
say

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc A CLI task manager
#help task is used to manage processes running on the computer. It runs in several modes: task list, task kill.
task list is used to list all tasks on the computer.
task kill is used to kill the specified process if you have enough rights to do so. Requires the provess PID, which can be viewed by using "task list".
Syntax: task <list|kill> [pid]
Examples:
task list # List all tasks
task kill 12831831623 # Kill the process with the specified process id
task

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
#desc A port utility
#help port is a utility to upload and download files using computer ports. There are several subcommands: port open, port close, port download
port open opens the specified port and uploads a file
port close closes an opened port
port download fetches file from other computer's port
Syntax:
port open <port> <file>
port close <port>
port download <ip> <port>
Examples:
port open 12415 file.txt # Opens port 12415 and uploads file named file.txt
port close 12415 # Closes port 12415
port download 127.0.0.1 8080 # Downloads a file located on port 8080 on computer with ip 127.0.0.1
port

i have a lot of data on this computer
i sure do hope nobody hacks into this computer
put passwords here later

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
___FLAG___!!! brick
___BRICK___!!!
#

#EXECUTABLE_HEADER___
say #22FF22 "Your code is: TROPHY2_REPLACE"
#

Messages.Content: you are a disgrace to our family

Args: I realised that I infodumped on you too hard, so this time you'll be figuring out everything by yourself
Though I'm pretty sure you can still manage it
So, your task is - connect to the target computer using 'remct' and run the DOOMSDAY.exe file
The problem is - you do not have 'remct' installed, so you'll need to get a package manager first
Download 'mario' package manager at MARIOIP_REPLACE on port MARIOPORT_REPLACE via the 'port' command (use 'help port' to learn how it works)
Okay, now let's talk about your target
Target computer is at ip TARGETIP_REPLACE
Good luck, and don't forget about the 'help' command! (for the love of god use it)
Good job! We'll continue tomorrow then - you can log off.
